subject: Re: [junit] When it matters most, don't forget your tests.
msgSnippet: I think asking candidates to do TDD in an interview is a waste of time. You have about forty-five minutes to find out how good that candidate is and if you ask
messageBody:
I think asking candidates to do TDD in an interview is a waste of time.

You have about forty-five minutes to find out how good that candidate is and
if you ask her to solve a problem and to begin by writing tests the TDD way,
you'll waste fifteen minutes seeing code that tests for easy cases, nulls
and exceptions. Not exactly enlightening.

I prefer to focus on coding problems and possibly mentioning tests and
hearing what they have to say about it. It's also perfectly okay with me if
all they talk about is "automated" tests and not TDD, I don't think that TDD
is a requirement to write good tests, nor does it tell me much about how
good that candidate is.

--
C�dric


On Sat, May 1, 2010 at 5:17 AM, Mike Forsberg <bigmike.f@...> wrote:

>
>
> This may be better in a blog post, which I will hopefully get to...
> but I'd like to pose two questions to the group first. Let's call it
> research.
>
> I've just completed a set of interviews and looking back on the coding
> questions. I realized that I never followed my test first mantra that
> I perform at home.
>
> First question, to those giving the interview... Would you ever
> suggest/remind a candidate of TDD style in his/her code?
>
> Second question, why on earth does a candidate, like myself, forget to
> write tests and incrementally improve their code? Do this show a lack
> of software development maturity?
>
> As a community reminder, and to myself.... don't forget TDD style on
> interviews.
>
>



--
